evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as documented in the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains robust against alternative explanations or evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as miscommunication, delayed responses, and lack of coordination observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal scenario.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal context, reflecting relevant operational and procedural characteristics.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as documented in the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: Assuming that absence of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication/coordination breakdown.
Assuming that the described behaviors reflect observable and evident breakdown during the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordinated actions preventing the incident, or if the incident was caused by procedural deviation unrelated to communication.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew intentions and actions; no explicit statements of communication failure but inferred from lack of warnings and assumptions.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal dataset.

assumptions: The historical evidence items (H1-H13) are part of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal dataset
No contradictory evidence exists outside the provided history items
defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback deviation was not recorded or documented in the dataset
If mechanical control failure evidence was found indicating equipment fault rather than procedural deviation
If environmental marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause without procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple history items (H1-H13) document the pushback event, the presence and knowledge of TRP markings, and the procedural actions of the tug instructor and trainee, supporting that the procedural deviation is documented and available in the dataset.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit dataset reference confirming availability; assumption that history items represent the dataset content

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as miscommunication, delayed responses, and lack of coordination observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: The described interactions and lack of warnings reflect communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordinated actions preventing the incident, or if mechanical failure was confirmed as primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe miscommunication and lack of timely warnings among crew members, consistent with communication/coordination breakdown key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew actions and assumptions about intentions during pushback

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal inspection phase dated 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal inspection data.

slot_statements.availability: The mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure is resistant to common defeaters, as the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase strongly supports the occurrence and impact of the failure.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase, indicating a relevant fault in the control systems.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal inspection phase dated 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking is considered part of the environmental or marking deficiency if it is small or not sufficiently visible.
The presence of the TRP and its characteristics on the day of the incident are as described in the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members, or if procedural deviations or communication breakdowns were the primary cause rather than marking deficiencies.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly describe the presence and visibility of the TRP marking and the environmental conditions affecting its identification, supporting the claim that an environmental or marking deficiency was present and identifiable during the pushback phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking deficiency alone caused the event or if crew communication and procedural factors also played significant roles

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure is inferred from the aircraft moving beyond the TRP despite operator actions.
No procedural deviation or communication breakdown sufficiently explains the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed a procedural deviation or communication failure causing the event, or if fault codes or repeated malfunctions were absent, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H6 directly describe the mechanical failure event with the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, indicating mechanical/control failure. H8 and H12 show no procedural deviation or communication breakdown that would explain the event, supporting mechanical failure over alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit fault codes or mechanical diagnostics are provided; inference is based on event description and absence of procedural or communication failures.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal context, reflecting relevant operational and procedural characteristics.

assumptions: The described behaviors and communications are representative of the key features of the procedural deviation
No other unreported factors influenced the pushback deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit communication failures or coordination breakdowns causing the deviation
If environmental or mechanical factors were primary causes rather than procedural actions

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine T3 prefinal scenario.

defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or warnings from headset operator or wingman that were ignored, or if environmental or mechanical factors were primary causes, this would weaken the procedural deviation identification.

No contradictory evidence about marking adequacy is present
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clear and adequate for the aircraft and pushback context
If procedural deviations or communication failures better explained the incident

assumptions: Crew statements accurately reflect their perceptions and actions
No significant unreported environmental or marking deficiencies influenced the event

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal inspection data.

assumptions: The TRP marking size and visibility as described are representative of the actual conditions during the incident.
The communication methods described (visual signals) are the primary means for stopping the tug.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed clear, unambiguous marking visibility and effective communication signals that were ignored, this would challenge the robustness of the environmental/marking deficiency identification.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly address the adequacy and visibility of the TRP marking and the communication signals, supporting that the environmental/marking deficiency identification is robust against defeaters.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not reachable or did not respond during critical communication windows
children_spec.test_procedure: Check communication logs and timestamps to verify if crew members responded within expected timeframes

children_spec.statement: Communication devices or systems were unavailable or malfunctioning during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and device logs to confirm operational status of communication equipment

children_spec.statement: Scheduled communication protocols were not followed, leading to missed or delayed information exchange
children_spec.test_procedure: Review procedural checklists and crew reports to identify deviations from communication protocols

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable or did not respond during critical communication windows

assumptions: Absence of warnings or responses from crew members during critical moments implies communication breakdown.
The headset operator, wingman, and trainee driver roles are relevant to communication availability.
defeaters: If evidence showed active, timely communication or warnings from crew members during the critical pushback phase.
If environmental or marking deficiencies were shown to be the primary cause rather than crew communication.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate crew members did not communicate warnings or respond during critical moments, supporting the claim of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether lack of communication was due to oversight or other factors; no explicit negative communication evidence.

Descriptions of events and roles are accurate and complete for the scope of this evaluation.
defeaters: If evidence of verified fault codes, repeat malfunctions, or bench checks indicating control system faults were presented, this would support mechanical/control failure.
If physical evidence showed control system anomalies or hardware faults, the conclusion might change.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, H12, and H13 directly describe procedural and communication issues during pushback, with no indication of mechanical or control failure; discriminator evidence favors procedural deviation and communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

children_spec.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance and operational logs for equipment readiness and any reported malfunctions during the pushback event

children_spec.statement: Availability of trained personnel to perform the pushback procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew rosters and training records to confirm presence and qualification of personnel assigned to pushback

children_spec.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between ground crew and cockpit during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication logs and recordings to verify if communication was established and maintained properly

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure is resistant to common defeaters, as the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase strongly supports the occurrence and impact of the failure.

defeaters: If direct fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure were found
If equipment fault traces or bench checks confirmed control malfunction separate from operator procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H8, and H12 indicate human procedural actions and decisions during pushback, with no direct evidence of mechanical/control failure; the continued movement past the TRP (H4) is not clearly linked to mechanical failure but rather to procedural or communication issues, favoring procedural deviation over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on human procedural accounts

node.statement: Scheduled communication protocols were not followed, leading to missed or delayed information exchange

assumptions: Assuming that the lack of warnings or alerts from crew members constitutes a failure to follow scheduled communication protocols
Assuming that the described interactions represent the full scope of communication during the pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed that communication protocols were followed but ignored due to other factors
If environmental or marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause rather than communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate that scheduled communication protocols were not effectively followed, as crew members did not warn or correct the instructor driving past the TRP, supporting the claim of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication protocols were formally established and consistently applied

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available at the time of the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if weather reports, lighting conditions, and other environmental data were recorded and accessible for the event timeframe

children_spec.statement: Marking information (e.g., signage, runway markings) was present and accessible during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify presence and accessibility of relevant markings through inspection reports, photographs, or sensor data

children_spec.statement: Communication or data systems providing environmental or marking information were operational and available
children_spec.test_procedure: Review system logs and maintenance records to confirm operational status of communication or data systems at the event time

node.statement: Communication or data systems providing environmental or marking information were operational and available

assumptions: Physical presence and knowledge of TRP markings imply operational and available environmental or marking information systems.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were obscured or malfunctioning communication systems prevented awareness of environmental information, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
Headset operator ... knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
Wingman ... it was not mandatory to use [marshalling wands]. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H11, and H13 indicate that environmental markings (TRP) were present, known, and visible, contradicting the claim that communication or data systems providing environmental or marking information were unavailable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about operational status of communication or data systems; assumption that physical markings and training imply availability.

node.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available at the time of the event

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 was visible and legible at the time of the event
Crew training and knowledge imply availability of relevant environmental data
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was obscured or not visible at the time of the event
If crew had no knowledge or training about the TRP markings
If environmental conditions (e.g., lighting, weather) prevented visibility of markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and location of the TRP environmental marking; H11 and H13 indicate crew awareness of the TRP, supporting that relevant environmental data was available at the time.
outcome.uncertainty_source: possible ambiguity about actual visibility conditions and crew perception

node.statement: Availability of trained personnel to perform the pushback procedure

assumptions: Presence of qualified personnel implies availability to perform pushback procedure.
No contradictory evidence indicating personnel unavailability or incompetence.
defeaters: If evidence showed lack of training or unavailability of qualified personnel, or if communication failures were documented as primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H9, H11, and H12 show trained personnel were present and involved in the pushback procedure, supporting availability of trained personnel and favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement on adequacy of training level or procedural compliance details; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness.

node.statement: Communication devices or systems were unavailable or malfunctioning during the incident

assumptions: Communication via interphone and headset operator implies devices were available and functioning
No mention of device malfunction or unavailability in the evidence implies none occurred
defeaters: If evidence showed headset or interphone system failures or unavailability during the incident
If crew or operators reported communication device malfunctions impacting coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, and H12 indicate communication devices and systems were functional and in use, with no reported malfunctions or unavailability, contradicting the claim of communication device unavailability or malfunction.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit statements about device malfunction; reliance on indirect inference from communication activity

node.statement: Marking information (e.g., signage, runway markings) was present and accessible during the event

defeaters: If evidence showed markings were obscured, damaged, or not visible to the crew during the event
If crew or tug operators reported inability to see or identify the TRP markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 indicate the TRP marking was present and physically defined, contradicting the claim that marking information was deficient or inaccessible.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in subjective assessment of marking adequacy and visibility

node.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between ground crew and cockpit during pushback

assumptions: Communication via interphone and visual signals constitute the primary communication channels between ground crew and cockpit during pushback.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective, clear, and timely communication warnings were given and ignored, or if communication equipment was faulty or unavailable.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, and H12 directly describe communication channels and their limitations during pushback, supporting availability of clear communication channels but also highlighting insufficiency of visual signals and lack of warnings, favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite availability; no explicit mention of communication failure.

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components show signs of wear or damage consistent with failure
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect mechanical components for physical damage or wear; absence of such signs lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Control system logs indicate anomalies or errors during operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze control system logs for error codes or unusual activity; no anomalies lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Failure mode matches known mechanical/control failure patterns in Boeing 737-8AS
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare failure characteristics with documented mechanical/control failure patterns; mismatch lowers probability

node.statement: Failure mode matches known mechanical/control failure patterns in Boeing 737-8AS

assumptions: No explicit mechanical fault codes are provided but inferred from uncontrolled movement beyond TRP
Communication failures are not supported by evidence as headset and wingman were present and communicating
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and operator procedural errors instead of hardware faults
If bench checks or fault codes indicated no mechanical/control failure

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H12) shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP despite controls and signals, indicating mechanical/control failure rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in operator actions and lack of explicit mechanical fault codes

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: No equipment fault evidence was found in the provided history items.
Communication and environmental factors did not contribute significantly to the deviation.
defeaters: If equipment fault traces or bench checks indicated a mechanical control failure, this would change the conclusion.
If communication breakdown evidence showed miscoordination causing the event, it would affect the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate no equipment fault or bench check issues, supporting procedural deviation as the cause of pushback beyond the TRP (H4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

children_spec.statement: Pushback procedure documentation is accessible to the ground crew at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if the pushback procedure manuals or digital resources were available and accessible to the ground crew during the pushback operation

children_spec.statement: Pushback equipment required for the procedure was operational and available
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and operational logs for the pushback equipment to confirm availability and functionality at the time of pushback

children_spec.statement: Qualified personnel trained in pushback procedures were present and available during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew rosters and training records to confirm presence and availability of qualified personnel during pushback

children_spec.statement: Communication systems required for coordinating pushback were available and functioning
children_spec.test_procedure: Test communication logs and equipment status reports to verify availability and functionality of communication systems during pushback

node.statement: Control system logs indicate anomalies or errors during operation

defeaters: Presence of control system logs indicating anomalies or errors during operation would change the assessment.
Verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions in control systems would support the claim.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates control system logs or anomalies/errors during operation; all evidence relates to human actions and procedural context without mention of mechanical or control system faults.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: Mechanical components show signs of wear or damage consistent with failure

defeaters: Presence of direct inspection or maintenance reports showing mechanical wear or damage
Bench checks or fault codes indicating control system malfunction
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates mechanical components showing wear or damage consistent with failure; all evidence relates to procedural and communication aspects during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: Pushback procedure documentation is accessible to the ground crew at the time of operation

assumptions: Training on TRP and procedures implies access to pushback procedure documentation
No contradictory evidence about documentation availability was provided
defeaters: If evidence showed the ground crew lacked access to or awareness of the pushback procedure documentation at the time of operation
If environmental or mechanical factors prevented adherence to documented procedures

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H9 and H11 directly indicate that pushback procedure documentation, including knowledge of the TRP, was accessible and known to the ground crew at the time of operation, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement confirming physical accessibility of documentation at the time, only inferred from training and knowledge

node.statement: Qualified personnel trained in pushback procedures were present and available during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed unqualified personnel or lack of training during the operation
If communication failures or environmental marking deficiencies were documented as primary causes
If mechanical control failures were identified affecting the pushback

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H3, H9, H11, and H12 show qualified personnel trained in pushback procedures were present and actively involved, supporting the claim. Discriminator analysis favors procedural deviation over communication breakdown or environmental or mechanical causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly supports personnel qualification and availability

node.statement: Communication systems required for coordinating pushback were available and functioning

assumptions: Communication via interphone and headset operator presence implies functioning communication systems.
No reported technical faults in communication equipment.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment malfunction or lack of communication attempts between crew members, or if headset operator or wingman failed to communicate critical stop signals.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, H11, and H12 show that communication systems were available and functioning, with multiple qualified personnel in communication roles and no indication of communication failure, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication system failure, but some ambiguity in effectiveness of visual signals and situational awareness.

children_spec.statement: Availability of environmental or marking data is documented and accessible in the system
children_spec.test_procedure: Check system logs and data repositories for presence and accessibility of environmental and marking data relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA engine T3 prefinal historical pair

children_spec.statement: Environmental or marking data is updated and maintained regularly to ensure current availability
children_spec.test_procedure: Review update records and maintenance schedules for environmental and marking data to verify timeliness and completeness

children_spec.statement: Environmental or marking data is available in a format compatible with analysis tools used for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA engine T3 prefinal historical pair
children_spec.test_procedure: Attempt to import and use environmental and marking data in the analysis tools to confirm compatibility and usability

node.statement: Pushback equipment required for the procedure was operational and available

No mechanical control failure implied by the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or bench check failures of the pushback equipment, or if the tug was unavailable or inoperable, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H9, H11, H12) shows the tug equipment was operational and available, with no indication of mechanical failure, supporting the claim that pushback equipment was operational and available.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is presented; uncertainty arises from lack of explicit mechanical check details.

node.statement: Environmental or marking data is available in a format compatible with analysis tools used for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA engine T3 prefinal historical pair

assumptions: Assuming that knowledge of TRP from training implies availability of marking data in compatible format.
Assuming that the description of TRP size and location corresponds to data usable by analysis tools.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were not visible or not compatible with analysis tools, or if the marking was ambiguous or missing, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H11, and H13 directly describe the presence and characteristics of the TRP marking and its visibility, supporting that environmental or marking data was available in a compatible format for analysis.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the adequacy and visibility of markings as some operators had not physically seen the TRP despite training.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs and communication device connectivity records to verify presence and reachability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and systems were operational and available for use
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance and system logs for communication equipment functionality during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze voice recordings, message logs, and witness statements for evidence of communication attempts

children_spec.statement: Communication attempts failed to result in effective coordination among crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate operational outcomes and crew reports to determine if communication attempts led to coordination
